inlineContent.text: TUIkit lets you build terminal applications using a familiar, declarative syntax inspired by SwiftUI. No ncurses, no C dependencies: pure Swift.
: 5 built-in phosphor themes with full RGB color support
: Configurable shortcut bar with context stack
: Pure Swift, no ncurses or other C libraries

abstract.text: A declarative, SwiftUI-like framework for building Terminal User Interfaces in Swift.
How keyboard input flows through TUIkit: from raw terminal bytes to your view handlers.
A value that describes the purpose of a button.
A modifier that presents an alert dialog when a binding is true.
A view that displays text in the terminal.
A navigation split style that attempts to maintain the size of the detail
content when hiding or showing the leading columns.
Defines the type of a row in a List, controlling selectability and focus behavior.
The edges of a view.
A collection of Unicode symbols commonly used for keyboard shortcuts.
A container view that groups content with optional header and footer.
Extracts the badge value from a view if it’s wrapped in a BadgeModifier.
Manages focus state across the application.
A scrollable list with keyboard navigation and single selection.
A result builder for composing table columns.
Internal modifier that layers an overlay view on top of the base content.
System status bar items that are always present.
Protocol for persistent storage backends.
Central service for posting and managing notifications.
A control for secure text entry, where the display masks the user’s input.
Configure the shortcut bar at the bottom of the terminal.
A navigation split style that resolves its appearance automatically based
on the current context.
A toggle style that displays a leading label and a trailing switch.
A horizontal row of buttons.
A stub modifier for list row separators.
The appearance and behavior of a toggle.
An interactive radio button group for single-selection from multiple options.
A property wrapper that reads and writes to persistent storage.
The style of a text view.
A storage backend that persists data to a JSON file.
A control that displays an editable text interface.
A modifier that displays a decorative badge on a view.
A protocol for views that can receive focus.
A protocol abstracting terminal operations for testability.
A modifier that fills the background of a view with a color.
The visual style of the status bar.
A view that stacks its children on top of each other (z-axis).
A set of vertical edges (top and/or bottom).
A flexible spacer that fills available space.
A control for selecting a value from a bounded linear range of values.
A view that arranges its children horizontally.
A navigation split style that reduces the size of the detail content to
make room when showing the leading column or columns.
A scrollable table with columns, keyboard navigation, and selection.
A visual separator between views.
A storage backend that uses UserDefaults.
A result builder that constructs arrays of radio button items for use in
The visual style of a track-based control like ProgressView or Slider.
A declarative, SwiftUI-like framework for building Terminal User Interfaces in Swift.
Navigate between interactive elements using the keyboard.
Horizontal alignment for VStack and similar containers.
A result builder that constructs scene hierarchies from closures.
Build your first terminal application with TUIkit.
A control that toggles between on and off states.
A modifier that strips all styling from content and replaces it with
a uniform dimmed appearance using only two colors.

Describes where to load an image from.
A preference key for the navigation title.
A view that arranges its children vertically.
Represents a badge value that can be Int or String.
A List row with type information for selection and focus handling.
A view that shows the progress toward completion of a task.
Manage reactive state in your TUIkit application.
Understand the layer model and rendering pipeline of TUIkit.
The visibility of the leading columns in a navigation split view.
The base protocol for scenes in TUIKit.
Visibility options for list row separators.
A toggle style that displays a checkbox followed by its label.
A type that specifies the appearance and interaction of navigation split
views within a view hierarchy.
Executes a view closure and renders it once.
Pass data from child views up to their ancestors.
A control that performs increment and decrement actions.
Understand the two-pass layout used by stacks and other layout containers.
Represents a frame dimension that can be a fixed value or infinity.
Edge insets defining padding on each side.
An interactive button that triggers an action when pressed.
A view that applies flexible frame constraints to its content.
A modifier that disables selection for a view within a List.
A padded, optionally titled container with background support.
A list style that uses borders, inset padding, and section grouping with alternating row colors.
A list style that uses minimal visual styling with no borders or backgrounds.
The current version of TUIkit.
Understand how a TUIkit application starts, runs, and shuts down.
Understand how TUIkit turns your view tree into terminal output: one frame at a time.
A modifier that adds a key press handler to a view.
The selection mode for a list or table component.
Tracks focus state for a specific element.
The visual style of a spinner animation.

creating items only as needed.
A vertical menu displaying a list of selectable items.

Manages the status bar state for the running application.
A modifier that adds padding around a view.

) is active.
